For a two player co-op game with good ways to work together and to piss each other off and kill each other all at the same time this is amazing.  The later levels (after the tutorials) are long and detailed and quite pretty.  It really is great fun.  

If, however, you find games like gang beasts, where you spend a lot of the game trying to get the character to do what you want, frustrating then this probably isn't for you.  It's not a 'bugs are fun' game like goat sim, it's more a 'physics are fun' game.

Human: Fall Flat is one of the funest games out there. With friends this game is some of the best entertainment you can get. The level design is fun, not so much challenging but me and my friends found ourselves on the same bit for hours just messing around; that's one the good things about this game - the replay ability. I've played the same level three times but still found myself in new perdicaments each time. But, keep in mind, i'm talking about the multiplayer here, not the singleplayer. You would get a fraction of the enjoyment and playtime as you would with multiplayer, playing the game singleplayer. Messing around with friends is what truley makes this game fun, probably the main reason everyone plays it. 

I got the game for half price(£6), which is one of the best £6 i've spent and I can say that price is very generous, but I'm not sure this game is worth £12. Fair enough it the game has a lot of replayabilty, I have 8.4 hours and I'm still not done, but the core game(i'f you just play it normally) is very short. A lot of people have mentioned it their reviews, the core game maybe has like 2 hours of gameplay. If you were to get this game, I would make sure to get it while it's on sale. 

The customisation is decent, not a lot of variation but the workshop opens up the door for that. There is a wide variety of skins of there and the fact you can import pictures leads up to some funny moments. 

All in all, I give this game a 8.1/10

This is a brilliant little game. Part platforming, part environmental puzzles and part physics playground, it is best enjoyed with a friend or two, either in split-screen (why don't more games do this nowadays now that we have giant 4K flatscreens?) or online. The complex and subtle physics even work pretty much exactly how you'd expect them to. With the correct network settings, there's pretty much no noticeable lag online either. 
The characters are very expressive, even though they don't have facial features by default (you can customize them of course and give them beards and funny hats). When I played through the game with the friend and didn't have voicechat, we merely pointed and mimed things when coordinating our next moves. 
All in all, a lot of fun and well worth the asking price.

Wish I could reccommend this game, but I can't.

I played through it co-op and some of it was enjoyable. However, the designers desperately need to learn how to create more interesting levels.

When you start playing this game you might THINK that it's the sort of game that has well-hidden secrets and all sorts of clever things like that, but in reality, every nook and cranny in every level winds up being completely pointless and underwhelming. My friend and I stopped even bothering with out-of-bounds exploration by the 3rd level because it never paid off.

At the end of the day you're left with a barely-competent puzzle game. The only real challenge is fighting against sluggish controls to perform repetitive tasks. If you buy it on sale and play it co-op, there is enjoyment to be had, but it's not a very good game.

[b]Wow I'm quite impressed with [i]Human: Fall Flat[/i].[/b] I don't typically go for the wonky physics-based puzzle games, but there is a reason this is a top seller. It's very fun, and very well put together. It spoon feeds strategy to you until you have your bearings. It's never made me rage quit, and even got me to chuckle a few times. They are still pumping out content, and the multiplayer aspect is icing on the cake.

[i]Essentially, you are controlling a dude and interact with the world by operating his left and right arm seperately.[/i] You are gonna want a controller for this. You can carry stuff around, and pull yourself up from ledges. It gets a little fancy, but not too fancy. The puzzles vary, but it's usually the put-the-box-on-the-button kind of deal.

[b]Pros:[/b]
+Very  polished and easy to play. The graphics are becoming more and more charming for me.
+It holds your hand until you get your bearings. They make the learning curve easy.
+The levels are interesting little stand-alone sandboxes that even have little secrets in store to reward those that want to stray from the main path.
+It's quite addicting because the puzzles are just challenging enough. No rage yet from me.
+There is a lot of content already, but more stuff is being added. Workshop support is being added, as well as all kinds of new skins.
+The music and lighting and ambience are very well done.
+Multiplayer is a blast.

[b]Cons:[/b]
-None that I can think of.

[b]What a pleasant surprise.[/b] I think this is worth full price.

[h1]First hour review[/h1]
No, I won't be refunding this game. Never in my life.
It is way too fun for that. The graphics are awesome, and so is optimization.
It has some humour in it, very unique characteristics, and lots of details in each level / map, that were still made while the developer probably knew only a few people would see.
Each level is challenging, but not too much, and very fun.
The first levels are simply perfect, the introduction to the mechanics are on point.

There is also the free (yes, no lootboxes or paid skins!) character customization, and each character can be shared on the Workshop.

And now, with the future Workshop addition (probably, not confirmed I think) to make our own levels, the game will be completely worth it!

If you enjoy games with goofy controls and the slapstick comedy of physics based ragdoll people trying to solve puzzles then you'll love Human Fall Flat. 
  
On the surface it looks like a pretty stupid game. You're messing around with your friends, throwing each other off of cliffs, sometimes solving a puzzle. What isn't immediately obvious is how much there is to explore and do in each of the levels (ending with Aztec as of Dec. 30 2017). There were so many moments playing this game where I yelled "THAT ACTUALLY WORKED???"  Some of the puzzle solutions make perfect sense but aren't possible without some kind of scripting in a more normally controlled game. I'm going to avoid spoiling them, but if you're a creative thinker you'll have a great time trying to break puzzles and explore placed you're not supposed to go (except you'll almost always find that you were, indeed, expected to make it there). It's a game that's packed full of secret little tasks that give you acheivements. 
  
The multiplayer as it currently stands is pretty good. People that I hosted said they experienced pretty bad latency when they tried to jump, but otherwise things seemed to work flawlessly. Even when our characters were hopelessly entangled we were able to both see ourselves hanging onto the correct body parts. On top of working surprisingly well it's just hilariously fun. 
  
If you're only interested in the single player I think you'll still find satisfaction in the game. The puzzles are all possible alone and interesting enough that you don't need other people goofing around to make them interesting. The game also has a fairly easy and fun speedrun if you're into that.

Very good body horror/movement horror/hand cramp game.

I want to start off by saying this is one of the VERY few games that I've played in a long time that I've enjoyed this much. While single player is definitely an option, playing with friends is an absolute *must*, as I don't think we went more than 2 mins in the entire playthrough without cracking up to the point of tears/out of breath over the dumbest scenarios or yelling "that worked?!?" / "No way!" / "Wait, what?!". 

The simplicity (yet small learning curve to "master") of the controls + (hilarious) physics based mechanics + puzzle solving + friends = an absolute blast. I highly recommend this game for anyone looking to: 

 * just have a good time laughing with friends
 * coming up with creative solutions to puzzles (and even finding shortcuts/alternative solutions)
 * enjoy just messing around in a game every so often

This game is one of the funniest games I have ever played. Everytime I play this with my friends I am brought to tears at least once. The game is great about allowing you to solve puzzles in multiple ways. It likes to imply the "correct" way to do them frequently, but still leaves the options available. It is a game where you will think of some crazy tactic to try and beat the puzzle, and it works, and that is not only funny but a great feeling. I can't give any genuine negative about this game.
WARNING: The 2 buttons "Reload Checkpoint" and "Restart Level" are right next to eachother on the pause menu. Do NOT accidenly hit "Restart Level" instead of "Reload Checkpoint", you will be brought to the very beginning of the level and will hvae no way of going back to the point you were at originally. There is no warning button upon hitting "Restart Level" so if you accidently click it, it's game over. The reason I put so much effort toward this is that this one small flaw was nearly enough to make me write a negative review, but I love the game too much for that to completely change my review.

Although, you really shouldn't buy this game if you plan on playing alone.

Get some friends.

[list]
    [*]Fun to play ALONE & WITH OTHERS

This game is truly something special. The climbing physics and mechanics keep you hooked playing alone, and promote exploration and ways for the player to figure out how to complete a puzzle faster. Playing online or with friends allows you to explore the puzzles in new and unique ways.


    [*]Both control schemes (KB+M & Controller) work well

Both control schemes make you FEEL like you're putting work into lifting/climbing stuff. It's an abstract kind of feel, but once you get used to it, it feels VERY rewarding.


    [*]Works on a wide variety of hardware and OSes

Compatible with Linux (SteamOS), Windows, and Mac. Rock solid 60FPS on both my gaming-oriented desktop, and my half-baked potato laptop. Runs at 144FPS solid at 1920x1080 settings maxed out on the desktop (i5-6600k + R9 290), Runs at 60FPS solid at 800x600 settings minimized  on the laptop (i5-2550m + Intel HD 3000). The fact that I'm able to get 60FPS on a laptop without any dedicated graphics whatsoever is a true testament to how well optimized this game is for the lower end PC's too.

[/list]

This game has no right to be as fun as it is. It looks like streamer bait, just wonky physics meant to have youtubers joke until you buy it, but it's actually great to do with at least one other person. The puzzles are free-form solve how you want to and the levels are actually decent. I just wanted to throw my friend off a cliff repeatedly, but I ended up playing several days straight.

Let me just start off by thanking the wonderful developers. The amount of work and dedication put into this game is something that is not matched even by big title games. I have seen so many good ideas fall into limbo because the developers either bit off more than they could chew, made enough money and just gave up on the game, or are incompetent. I can say with confidence that these developers are not like that. With the constant updates since release, I'm sure this game will stay good. 

On to the game. It was a hard idea to work with, because it would have to nail the line between too easy and over frustratingly hard. I think it did it better than any other game of this type. I have put in quite a few hours in this game, and replayed the story with different people, and I can say that it is still yet to be boring. The possibilities are endless, and you can mess around for hours without completing any part of the puzzle and still have fun. Since there is no story and it is sorta open world, you can get your own experience out of it depending on what you put in. Sure, you could break the game and skip the puzzles, but you don't get any fun out of it. That is why this game is a masterpiece.

This game is delightfully absurd. It reminds me of a browser game called noodleball. both games feature a "drunk baby" waddling around doing stuff. I love how basic and open the levels are, as well as the puzzles. I tried the online portion but was slain by the lag dragon. I don't blame you, I use a particularly surly potato as a computer, so no hard feelings. I am sure that all of the higher vegetables run the game even smoother. I may have run with the vegetable parrables a little too long. Now that I think about it, were there any actual vegetables in the game? And for that matter, why would I bother to drag the lantern into the secret tunnels below the crashed train? I was expecting some easter eggs, jumpscares, cake, something! But no, Kevin and I (I named the lantern Kevin) wasted an hour just trying to get over that little swinging hatch so I could see where I was going. In conclusion, the only suggestion that I have would be to add something to any hard to reach areas, as a reward, for anyone bored enough to spend more time than they needed to just to get to the same place.

A 3D platforming puzzle adventure. Basically everything about this game is great (with the exception of the story, but there really isn't one there anyways so I can overlook it). The controls feel really smooth yet still goofy in a fun way. The soundtrack feels a little off at times, but that's just my opinion. The physics are very fun to play around with, even more so with friends. I only have a few complaints, the first of which being the levels. The graphics for everything is very simple style, very aethetically pleasing and easy for you computer to run, but the layout is mildly questionable at times. Occasionally, it is unclear as to where you are supposed to be headed, but I believe that is all part of the fun. My other complaint is that the levels are designed with the intention of it being solved with only one player, so when another is added, some of the puzzles can be cheated and altogether skipped with a bit of team work, but again, all in good fun. 

Overall I'd give this game an 8/10, and I can strongly recommend it to anyone who's a fan of puzzles, platforming, and physics.

Pros:
1. Puzzles with multiple possible solutions, emphasis on creative problem solving.
2. Co-op modes add a lot of fun and laughs.
3. Customization options for bob.
4. Low poly graphics with good simple textures and lighting (I find that art style visualy relaxing).
5. Open exploration options beyond just the puzzles and acheivements.

Cons:
1. Too much wobble. While it can make for some hillarious moments, and adds a bit of challenge, the excessive wobbling can be frustrating for some of the puzzles and the resulting camera shifting around makes me nauseous. I have chronic headaches which sometimes have visual triggers and things like the excessive wobbling can make them worse.

2. Sometimes in co-op people will grab onto you and throw you off stuff or prevent you from moving, this can sometimes be pretty funny, though occasionally some players abuse this feature and harrass others.

Suggestions:
1. Please give us a way to select the degree of wobble to our liking. 
2. An option to make it so bob cannot be grabbed by other players. I suggest this just be an ability and not a toggle because more commonly other players will be helpful and assist you up ledges or prevent you from falling off something. So, just some sort of "let go" type of button for those times when other players are not being helpful.
3. Run or sprint, because fun.
4. Better free climbing options. I really like open exploration of the maps in addition to the puzzle solving. Right now there is a sort of swing side to side option to slowly scale vertical surfaces which seems to limit how much higher you can reach up each time. I'd like to see that limit removed or some other option put into place.
5. Improved item handling. See player wobble.  
6. Day and night cycles.
7. More maps and more complex puzzles.

Humans Fall Flat is well worth the money and a nice game to play with friends. The puzzles have multiple routes to explore and things to do, and the general feel of the game is very fun and polished. 
The art style is simplistic, but IMO effective in creating a soft looking world to flail around in. The soundtrack is also unique, at points it felt over melancholic, so ultimately I turned it down and listened to something more suitable for the game.
The game controls very well and no bugs were present thankfully. Designing your character is a lot of fun and with the new 8 player multiplayer, things should be really picking up!

A word for the developers: The 8 stages in game are a lot of fun to do, so more stages are always welcome! Alternatively, games like Portal 2 live on because of the Workshop, so perhaps Steam workshop integration might be a thing in the future?

Human Fall Flat is a physics puzzle game which is really special and hillarioudly fun to play. 

In single player, it's a fun adventure, getting froma area to area, exploring new scenery and finding ways to solve the puzzles facing you.

In multiplayer, it's that but a WHOLE lot more. Maybe you'd take the *friendly helper* role and help your friends up when they can't quite reach the big rock you're standing on or hold down a button so they can cross a chasm. Or perhaps you'd take the *lovable prankster* role and surround your afk friends with rocks or toss them off cliffs for a laugh. There's just so many ways to mess with each other but also have fun and solve each puzzle together.

And last but not least, controls. I find that the keyboard controls are very easy to use, and that was an important thing for me as I have difficulty playing games with bad or wonky controls.

Insanely unique and fun physics based puzzle game. It runs like a charm, no bugs to report. And it now has ONLINE coop for up to 8 players! And you can quickly see that having more players is beneficial. I haven't completed the game yet but I feel like I'm near the end but I don't want it to end! Well worth the $15 regular price at this time. OH and you can play 2p split screen as well :) Highly recommend for puzzle or physics fans.

This is the first and probably last review I'll ever write.

So Sunday afternoon at around 3:15pm my Brother messages me saying "Look at a game called Human: Fall Flat"
Reading the random title I decided to check it out as sometimes he does find good games.
As soon as I saw the tag "Physics Based" I was sold (If ya'll know any other good co-op physics based games let me know in the comments) because I knew that they usually result in endless lols and good times had by all.

So I think f*ck it and buy the game for £12 and load up the gameplay trailer. Within I'd say 5 seconds of watching I had started laughing and I mean proper belly laughing. Eager to play I installed the game and we made a lobby. After 20 minutes of headbutting a train my brother finally joined me and we set out on the journey with high hopes.

8 hours, 2 headaches caused by laughing, 2 500mg of paracetamol and 7 spliffs later we both logged off with new found hope for the gaming industry and various short term ailments caused by extreme laughing and snorting (with me actually shedding a tear later on in the game)

Whoever is responsible for this masterpiece I say thank you to you.
Buy this game, if you spend £12 this Christmas spend it on this game.
Don't worry about Christmas presents and bills and food for your children just buy this and have a jolly good time.

It's ridiculous and ridiculously fun.
It doesn't matter if you make a mistake, or if you pickup your friend and throw them off the map/slap them around a bit, just try again. It's just good old fashioned fun, like trying to perform surgery on an orange with a set of chop-sticks, it is doable, provided you practice enough.
There are different levels (not a lot, but plenty to keep you busy, for now) with varying levels of difficulty and it seems there is often more than one way to solve the puzzles, you'll find some things easy and other things a good challenge.

Does have a few glitches with skin editing... And occasional FPS spike (which I assume eventually will get some optimization)... And dodgy multiplayer if your too far away from the host, but overall it runs well, haven't actually experienced a crash of any form yet.
Biggest complaint, even though some of the levels are huge, there's not a lot of levels to select from. Fingers crossed for workshop level's later on. :3

I don't often have positive things to say about games, especially with the poor state of game development being spewed out by a lot of "gaming" companies, but Human: Fall Flat is a keeper for anyones library.
Definitely had my money's worth of giggles.

Once you get the hang of "Human: Fall Flat" it's Ok.  That said, there were quite a few things that completely infuriated me about this game and I would be highly neglectful if I didn’t include them in this review.

First is the control, or rather oddity that is considered control.  Your character is basically a complete rag doll that’s somewhat controlled from the mid-section.  That meaning, it seemed as if the legs were there just to flop around, without actually holding you up.  This would become somewhat frustrating in areas where you really needed to know where your footing was.  With your legs flailing around during every jump it was sometimes extremely difficult to make a precision maneuver, and in a game where precision is sometimes the only way to move on, it can become quite rage-inducing.

Secondly, it seemed like many maps allowed you to very easily skip the majority of the map to move onto the next area.  As the game progressed it seemed like the linear design of the maps failed heavily.  An example, when I reached the “boat” level I pretty much didn’t have to do anything.  I made my way over to the dry river, walked up to the dam at the top, “bounced” across the rail that leads to the top of the waterwheel, and opened the exit door.  From there I just had to jump off the diving board and I was done that level.  I knew I missed a LOT of content there, but unlike a good linear puzzle there was really nothing forcing me to solve the tests that were laid out in front of me.  This continued, to some extent, in the battery area.  When you were supposed to seek a way to get the battery down from the statue, I just ran back through the shortcut to the start and grabbed the very first battery.  I skipped a whole section of puzzles and went straight to the boilers.  The very last map was even worse.  After wedging open the door I figured out I could “jam” the elevator using the sticks I was given at the start and then simply use the cube to climb up to the top of the elevator area.  From there I went right to the temple and jumped in.  I must have skipped 80-90% of that final level... Even though there was a lot of imagination used, this is a sign of poor map design.  A player shouldn’t be able to skip over entire sections of a level using the tools you’ve given them.

My final gripe, which will sound funny considering my last paragraph, is the lack of content in this game.  Each map seemed to introduce new things however that specific map was the only place those new things were used.  For example, the forklift.  You basically used it for a whole 30 seconds and that’s the last time it’s used.  The haul truck, you do one load of coal and that’s it.  Likewise for the boats, you use them for one quick thing and you never see them again.  It almost seems like a waste of perfectly good coding.  Why not add more levels with those same objects, although have the player use them in a different way?  Like maybe having to use the boat to transport something.  Or have the player use the forklift to position a pallet to climb to something?  I mean, there are many ways you could use these vehicles to solve different puzzles.  It was really sad to see such limited use of them.  The wiring and batteries was yet another missed opportunity.  Why not make an actual wiring puzzle?  Like, instead of just hooking 2 wires up between a battery/generator you have the player have to actually use multiple wires to build a circuit.  Hook up actuators to levers and a power source, etc.  There are so many simple circuit diagrams online it would be really easy to incorporate one into your game as a puzzle.  According to Steam I completed this game in under 4 hours, and that was without doing anything I would classify as cheating.  To me, that seems overpriced.

Some people might argue with me on this next topic, that being replayability.  While I can see that some people might find a lot of replay value in this game, for me personally it’s not there.  I really have no desire to go back and see what content I might have missed, or how I could have completed puzzles differently.  After the first couple of maps the novelty of the game wore off for me and it became a push to reach the end.  I didn’t really find that “spark” that would draw me back to playing through the game again.  Yes, there were some interesting aspects to the game, but nothing I’d want to relive.  The only real replay value in this game would be for those who are looking to join the speed running competition.  Personally, I couldn’t be bothered with that nonsense considering the only talent involved in speed-running is how quickly you can use exploits and glitches.  That's not skill.  It's akin to using a performance enhancing drug during the olympics.

At any rate, I don’t think I can recommend this game.  As a puzzle game, which is what this seems to be trying to be, I really didn’t find it that difficult.  The puzzles were extremely easy to solve, with the only frustration being when you couldn’t get your avatar to do what you were trying to get it to do.  That would fall more into the category of “fighting with bad controls” than it would be puzzle solving.  The game is interesting, no doubt about that, but it’s not something I’d discuss with friends around the water cooler.  Thus I can’t recommend it to you either.

One thing to note, I haven’t tried their alpha version of multiplayer.  This might be where this game shines.  The frustration at trying to control your avatar could very easily turn to all kinds of humor when playing and joking around with friends.  My review is solely based on the single-player experience.

This game is a stellar work of art. 
There are so many things that make this game a masterpiece, but so I don't spend the next 10 years gushing over this jewel I'll focus on the most important and incredible portion of the game: 

The Story.

I can't remember the last time a story in a videogame has moved me like Human: Fall Flat. 
I was unsure when I first dove in, but even by the end of the first act I was more than hooked.
By the end of the game, I was in tears. 
I don't want to spoil any important details, but trust me when I say that the characters and world of HFF will immerse you totally. The character's interactions with eachother are second to none, it's like they took a recording of people from real-life and used it. Mad props to the voice actors, their obvious dedication to this game shines in the dialogue.
If you take anything from this review, let it be that the story of this gem will move like never before.

The only thing I could possibly say is a bit off about this game is the gameplay. 
It's clear that they focused more on the art and storyrather than the engine, which is perfectly fine. However, playing with the physics in the world was just boring. It feels like the whole "physics puzzle" gimmick was thrown in more as a last-minute addition rather than a core component. 

TL;DR
Fantastic story, incredible voice acting and characters, boring gameplay. A must-buy for lovers of in-depth story.

A fantastic,fun,silly physics based puzzle game with online and couch co-op built in.

I was honestly expecting the controls to be not all great, usually in games that use an actual physics engine for moving characters and not animations tends to not have the best controls however in Human Fall Flat they feel great, they walk a fine line of being responsive enough and kinda fiddly for comedic effect without ever frustraiting you or making it feel like its the game fault if you fail. The few levels it offers will take about 4 to 6h to complete, depending on how much exploration you do.
What i love most about it is the fact that every puzzle has multiple solutions, a fair amount of which  i don't think even the devs noticed and it's all thanks to the great,fun physics engine it has. Levels also offer a lot of exploration, tons of secrets and easter eggs can be found which adds a good replay reason to try and find all the hiden things in a level. Achievements are also well done, trying to do some of em' was really fun with a partner, such as trying to perfectly stack 4 boxes or trying to balance ourselves on a moving giant bolder as its roling down.

Only con of the game is well its lenght, in about 4 to 6h you'll be done as it doesn't have  too many levels , still it's not expensive and the few hours of content are very good quality. I hope the devs add steam workshop support one day with a level edditor, that would extend the game's life by ten fold.

So yeah  i strongly recommend it, it's a ton of fun.

I don't think I have ever played a puzzle game (with friends mind you) that so readily and frequently falls into tomfoolery with hilarious consequences. Now I have not played this game by myself, and I wouldn't recommend it. This game is truely meant to be enjoyed with friends. The game play is extremely difficult at times and the physics of the game can make some of the puzzles difficult, but any potential frustration usually dissolves into gut busting laughter, and the game offers multiple ways a task may be accomplished. My only complaint about the game is that there isn't more of it as between you and a couple friends the game can be completed within a couple hours. However, the replayability of the game has great potential and how much fun it is to play with friends makes replaying the game a pleasure. My only wish? More content in future DLC's. Fingers crossed for sure! This game is worth every single cent spent on it. 100% recommendation.

This is a physics engine game, but with a nice graphical style. There's no doubt about that. The puzzles usually aren't too hard. The main challenge actually appears to be getting your character to do what you want. Imaging having elastic bands as arms equipped with strong on/off electric magnets and then trying to do something that requires precision. Those are your controls for manipulating the world. As suggested, a game controller is really what you'd want to use.

Played this game through split-screen and had a blast. Since the addition of online, now the great joys can be relived with more players. This is a game to play with a group of friends, to get the full experience. 

The game itself is a puzzle plat-former, however, with the quite silly physics, you can tackle the puzzles in numerous ways, to downright breaking them. However, the real fun wasn't in the solving of the puzzles in the first place, but rather discovering what you are capable of doing within the game in the process. As you learn more, you discover new ways to cause mischief. With a group of friends doing just the same, well, things get out of control.

For example; we had a vehicle, and one of us got the engine started, but fell off right after. So in an attempt to stop it, one of us stood in front of it only to have the vehicle pass right over without a hitch. Another ran after it and attempted to grab it and caught the tire, only to be spun uncontrollably as we watched both our friend and the vehicle tumble off the ledge.

With the right group of friends, I highly recommend you give this game a go.

This game was pretty fun most of the time.
However, when it was not fun, I had never been so close to punching a hole through my monitor. It was an enjoyable time for the few dollars I paid, but certain puzzles were such utter garbage that I wanted to kill myself. Even if you knew the solution to a puzzle in your head, the gang beasts-esque controls made actually executing the solution excruciating.
Have you ever played Gang Beasts? or QWOP?
Imagine having to solve complex physics puzzles with those controls. In short bursts, its a funny and enjoyable time, but by the last level when the game starts asking you to platform around through time-based solutions it's genuinely painful.
If you only play about 3/4 of this game, it's rad, but I highly recommend you stop around the castle level.

[b]Think: Gang Beasts, but more puzzles and climbing[/b], that's what this game is. However, [u]I would rate Human: Fall Flat much higher than the aforementioned title[/u] for many reasons:

- It has one of the best physics based puzzelers I have played, ever.
- Controlling your character feels amazing, it's simple, but works so well.
- There is a decent character editor.
- The multiplayer experience is fantastic; just hop into a game and help solve puzzles with others.
- The game is filled with amazing set pieces; you can pretty much drive or tamper with whatever machine you see (my favorite being the cargo ship on the water level :D).
- There is more than one way to solve each puzzle, making for a really satisfying experience when you solve something your own way.

   I have had a blast with this game! I was skeptical when I purchased it initially, but since then I have become infatuated by it and will totally come back to it again and again. The only gripes I have are the occasional bug and that there are only a few levels at this moment, but if there was a level editor the replayability of this game would be awesome!

   Honestly, on sale or not, just buy this game and maybe a copy or two for your friends!

Human: Fall Flat is brilliatn! 

Does it have it's flaws? Absolutely! However, they are so minor that  the fun you will be having just from playing this will be so worth it. 

There are only 2 things that I would say are wrong with it.

1! Very short game.  One friend and I can complete the whole game in 10 minutes. (Speed runs!) 
    -Side Note: If this is intended? AWeSOME! If not? I think we broke your game.

2. NO LEVEL CREATOR! Hell! I think this game would shine SO HARD! If there was a steam workshop where people could create levels and you could check out other peoples hard work. 

Now for a list of THE GREATEST THINGS EVER!

1. Physics Based Puzzles
2. You can pick your friends up and throw them off the puzzles
3. Creative puzzles 
4. Beautiful art style 
5. You can pick friends up and troll them
6. Co-op puzzles
7. Troll your friends
8. Laugh like crazy because even though you are being a douche, it's funny! IT'S FUN! 
9. Lasting memories of good times in a great game. Well worth the CAD $8.49.
I never had so much fun like playing Human Fall Flat! 100% recommended x)

Let me get this straight, you want me to tell you a review about this game? Whoever you are, you might as well go to the curators, because if you've come for a review on this game, you've come to the wrong place. However, if you have come for an outstanding chocolate chip cookie recipe, you've come to the right place.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients
1/2 cup (1 stick) unsalted butter
3/4 cup packed dark brown sugar
3/4 cup sugar
2 large eggs
1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
1 (12-ounce) bag semisweet chocolate chips, or chunks
2 1/4 cups all-purpose flour
3/4 teaspoon baking soda
1 teaspoon fine salt

Directions
1. Evenly position 2 racks in the middle of the oven and preheat to 375 degrees F. (on convection setting if you have it.) Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone sheets. (If you only have 1 baking sheet, let it cool completely between batches.)

2. Put the butter in a microwave safe bowl, cover and microwave on medium power until melted. (Alternatively melt in a small saucepan.) Cool slightly. Whisk the sugars, eggs, butter and vanilla in a large bowl until smooth.

3. Whisk the flour, baking soda and salt in another bowl. Stir the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients with a wooden spoon; take care not to over mix. Stir in the chocolate chips or chunks.

4. Scoop heaping tablespoons of the dough onto the prepared pans. Wet hands slightly and roll the dough into balls. Space the cookies about 2-inches apart on the pans. Bake, until golden, but still soft in the center, 12 to 16 minutes, depending on how chewy or crunchy you like your cookies. Transfer hot cookies with a spatula to a rack to cool. Serve.

5. Store cookies in a tightly sealed container for up to 5 days.

For a Rocky Road Bar:
1. Lightly butter a 9 by 13-inch baking pan. Make the batter as per cookie recipe and fold in 1 cup chopped walnuts along with the chocolate chips. Spread batter in prepared pan. Bake until the edges are light brown and the batter sets, about 45 minutes. Cool slightly and cover surface with 4 cups marshmallows and 1 cup chocolate chips. Broil at least 8 inches from the heat until marshmallows turn golden brown, about 2 minutes. (Keep an eye on the marshmallows, and turn the pan frequently--they go from golden to char in a wink.) Cool, cut and serve.

Human: Fall Flat invents an entirely new mechanic for interacting with a virtual world - all through attaching the left hand to your left mouse button, and the right hand to the right button. This simple interaction is thoroughly enjoyable to learn, while being suprisingly difficult it's still satisfying. The name of the game here is interaction and HFF does it incredibly well. Throw this in with the functional physics system and suddenly picking up a brick and throwing it over your character's shoulder becomes an immensely entertaining activity, for something so simple. 

The polygon art style suits the game well, and probably helps to keep it running so smoothly. The environments presented in the game are where the aesthetics really come into their own. The huge castle/fortress or aztec jungle etc, look great with the game's lighting, colours and shading. 

You have to play this game with friends. That's where it really shines. Hauling each other around, watching each other fuck up and fall off a cliff - hell, even watching them just try to plug a wire into a connector is so entertaining. 

The puzzles the game presents are super fun to work out. I'm usually the type who would rather google the solution than work it out for myself - but in HFF I wanted the satisfaction of figuring it out. It was just that fun. There's a somewhat steep learning curve in the mechanics, but nothing you can't eventually figure out - we even brute-forced our way through a few puzzles/doors without realising. 

Replayability: The second or third time round a few of the maps was still enjoyable. Again, mainly due to watching friends try to work out puzzles while I already knew how to do them. Still fun. The game also rewards you for treading off the main path. So the second time around, you look at every little nook and crany in the environment and start to think: "I wonder what's in/up/down there". And when you do get there - there's actually some content waiting for you. 

Negatives: the game ends. There's only so many maps, and so many times you can play the same puzzles. There's no real arcade mode to speak of, or any challenges aside from the steam achievements included. I would have a lot more hours on this game if there was just more levels or maps or game modes. 

Overall: The best physics game I've ever played - and one of the best party games I've ever played.

This is the best party game I have ever played in my entire life.
Everything about this game is absolutely perfect, aside from the length. If they add more levels, or a "level creator" of sorts, or give modders the ability to create their own levels and add them to a Worshop, then I could see myself sinking 10's of hours into it.
Even as it stands, it has a very high replay value. Each level always has something new to find. There's a ton of ways to get to the end of the level if you use your head. Get another player in the game with their new Online Multiplayer mode, and there are even MORE creative ways to beat the level. Get a bunch of people online at once, and there's no limit to the insane crap you can do.

This game is well worth the money, especially now that it has online multiplayer. And if they add more levels/the ability to create more levels, it'll go down in history as one of the best games I've ever had the pleasure of playing.

Wow, this game came right out of left field. An incredible game, Human Fall Flat is a co-op physics platformer where you throw your man around and grippy grab things with your hands to operate mechanisms and climb to the end of levels. The level sizes range from small to massive, there is an incredibly in-depth character creator that allows you to paint on your lil guy, and it's 8-player online. This is one of the most fun online experiences I've had in a long time. The way the players move is so oddly realistic, you'll find yourself just watching your teammates attempt to do basic things. It's a little bit lacking in levels, however, it appears that they are adding more *AND* adding workshop level support. Recommended for anybody.

Human: Fall Flat is a silly physics-based game where you have to complete numerous puzzles in order to move on throughout the levels. There are multiple different kinds of puzzles which keeps your brain ticking constantly. It supplies a singleplayer and multiplayer mode. You can either have a friends-only multiplayer match, multiplayer match with strangers or Split Screen with a friend (or as I like to call it, couch mode).

The graphics are pretty and they are all isometric which makes me love this game. Any game that includes isometric shapes in the graphic files will make me love the design. The best thing is that it is all simply designed and not too much effort, unlike most games, are put into the graphics. This is reasonable because the game is supposed to be funny and silly and having complex graphics will take that away. The animations and transitions are really well made. If you die (i.e Fall in lava or into the void) it simply changes to make it seem like you're falling from the sky and you land on the ground. The animations for the character is hysterical because if something hits you on the head, the top part of your character swings back but you can still carry on walking.

The multiplayer is a good idea indeed but unfortunately, you're going to run into these trolls who like to ruin your day. They grab hold of you and stop you from doing stuff by killing you. It can be very annoying when they only focus on one person. 

Overall, Human Fall Flat is worth every penny or cent or whatever for the singleplayer but for the multiplayer, I would recommend another game similiar called Gang Beasts. Thank you for reading.

This game is really fun, it made me laugh, and really made me interested to find interesting ways to get around the 9 levels currently in the game. You can tell that they really care about making interesting levels, as they all have various achievements and unique themes, like a factory/construction site, a power plant, and Aztec ruins. They are all really nice to look at, the Aztec level in particular having some really attractive architecture. Each level feels different, and the controls are very basic, but offer a lot of variation and strategies you can do. This game is even better with a mate, and you can also dress up the character to wear hazmat suits, police uniforms, Skiing gear.

There is one major problem with this game though: It can be extremely frustrating.

The controls, whilst offering a lot of the humour and value in the gameplay, also add in a lot of irritating quirks and confusing moments. For example, sometimes I will try to jump off of a ledge to grab another, but instead, the model just flops off the edge, and it seems to be because it can be quite difficult to judge when his feet are on the tip of the edge, but for the most part it won't stop you progressing. Another is with some levels, like Water, really showing how rowing a boat wasn't really a good use of the controls. I eventually got into some sort of system with rowing, but I never managed to get a grasp of the raft controls, as it seemed to just keep slapping into the beach or just not moving at all.

Levels are also very large, which on one hand is very enjoyable because you can't breeze through this game in 10 minutes unless you're very good at the puzzling and platforming, are sometimes unclear in their direction, and what feels like the right way to go, is in fact a huge skip past most of the level's content, so when you reach the end of the level, you may feel confused as to what the other things in the level are for. Aztec had this problem, where one box puzzle can skip almost 90% of the level's content. 

Overall, this game gets a solid 8/10, I had a lot of fun with it, and I can't remember if it has workshop support or not, but if it doesn't, it would hugely benefit from it.

I bought this game as part of bundle (three games). It's funny that this game was reason why I bought bundle and it's also the worst game in bundle. Beginning of game is fun and I liked narrator voice and tutorial videos, but after that there is nothing more than just endless walking without purpose. Would you like to roam through varied floating landscapes solving physics puzzles as a pudgy man with the body consistency of a gummy-bear? How about with a friend? If you answered "YES" then Human Fall Flat may be a game for you!

This game manages to be both fun and frustrating as you attempt to control your floppy man through a good number of themed levels (castle, construction yard, docks, ancient temple, etc). To progress through these locations you need to solve a lot of physics puzzles. Some are easy, some look easy but aren't. Some look hard. Some are just nonsense. But the game is oddly forgiving in some ways, especially when playing co-op, and while there may be a "correct" solution to most of the puzzles it won't stop you from getting up to serious high jinx  and abusing the physics system to "solve" them in a more...lets say "creative" way.

You primarily control you little man (who can be completely color customized and outfitted with funny clothes) by moving around and grabbing things with each left and right trigger being the grip of your left and right hand, respectively. Raising your arms up and down allow you to lift and pull yourself, your partner and other objects. Results vary from getting the object to exactly where you want to completely borking it all up in the most hilarious way. Add more complex interactions like trying to sync the oars on a rowboat or anything involving a combination of jumping and grabbing allows for a good challenge. The controls and frame-rate are smooth but sometime the camera is a little funky as it tries to deal with intervening objects as you flail your little man around. 

I won't go further into the types of things you can do in Human Fall Flat as a lot of the fun is finding those interactions for yourself. Safe to say that there are a LOT of different ways of interacting with the world and objects that can be used. Or misused. Or be broken. (Also water can sometimes be a real pain in the butt - grrrr). Regardless even the screenshots I used here (from the developers website) almost show to much.

There is a checkpoint system where if you fall off the world it resets you to the start of the puzzle that works most of the time, it can be a little frustrating in the longer stretches when you take a tumble near the end. In co-op it is a little more forgiving as long as one person reaches the checkpoint the other can use it as well. The method of reaching the check point as you fall is clever too as you just keep falling back to the start from where you fell off without interruption as if the world is one big wrap around.

I really like minimalist art style of the both the world design and the color pallet used. It is clear and easy to read as well as nice looking. The design of the world is both strange and humorous with a number of little gag bits added for fun. 

I really enjoyed my time with Human Fall Flat and the designers (No Breaks Games) have already released additional content since the game came out and hopefully will release more puzzle locations and features (as of this writing online co-op is coming soon) in the future. For $15 (or less, it goes on sale quite often) you get a good chunk of really fun puzzle solving game play.

Note : I only played Human Fall Flat in split-screen co-op mode so I don't know how any of it works as a single player experience, some of the puzzles we barely solved with the two of us, I have no idea how they would be solved solo.

I recently just got this game to play with my 5 year old son for his birthday. We love split screen and local coop games so I wanted to leave a review here for anybody who was on the fence about this game!  We finally beat the game recently together! 


Gameplay: 9
- From the start it was extremely easy to drop in 2 players for some local coop. This game is filled with various physics based puzzles where you are required to interact with the environment in logical ways to find a way to the end. There seems to be multiple ways to complete the levels which leads me to believe ther are tons of secrets to find! We also LOVED the customizable characters which were not in the game from the start so I hear. The game is great for local coop because when you get too far ahead it will teleport the other player to your location which was super helpful for progressing through the game with a toddler.

Controls: 10
- Charlie is only 5 so he is not completely capable of handling a mouse and keyboard setup yet but is vey skilled with an Xbox One controller. This game was perfectly suited for the controller and has very intuitive controls. Charlie had it figured it without the first couple of minutes and the game did a great job of introducing the more complicated mechanics slowly as you progressed.

Story: 9
- The narrator is great in the training videos; I love sarcastic tutorial videos and narrators. It allows for some fun dialogue moments where the narrator has awareness that the game is being played by somebody through the monitor. It gives off a vibe similar to Portal and The Stanley Parable so far! The world is full of mystery and not much was explained at the start which adds to our curiosity of everything around us.

Graphics: 9
- Low polygon artwork is a particular favorite of our family! I feel like this game in any other art style would not be the same and would take away from the world. Low polygon artwork pairs well with the developer's world and gameplay mechanics based around physics.

Overall: 9
- HIGHLY RECCOMEND for anybody looking for a splitscreen experience.  There are very few that are fun and work well lately and this is one that does everything right!



Here is a link to our gameplay video for anyone looking to see some actual game footage:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=svE4zAlywDc

It's fun for a while until you hit some particular challenge where you're just a victim of the inconsistent physics model.  That point came for me in Level 7 where you first encounter a giant slide that you have to use to cross a gap.  I was able to cross it once in about 50 tries.  At that point, it's not based on skill, it's based on your luck at getting that perfect set of physics variables right that you get enough momentum to get close enough to the other side with enough horizontal momentum to still allow you to grab and rise up onto the other side.

When there's challenges like that which are so biased towards luck rather than learned skill, it's time for me to uninstall a game.  I just don't have enough time in life to waste on something that won't allow me to pass things like that with learned skill after a period of time.

I'll uninstall it after this review.

The game is stupidly funny.

Apart from usual directional movement, you control a guy's two arms and try to do all sorts of things with them, like pushing a button, pulling a lever, carrying things and even climing. The fun part is that, since the game is physics-based, your guy can be wobbly when trying to use the arms, and have all kinds of stupid but laughable consequences.

CONS:
I thought this would be a nice, relaxing zen game, it is not. Be prepared to click (and possibly move your mouse) a lot. Oh, how could I forget: there is no option for full screen, it's a borderless window! So, if you have more than one monitor, you might accidently deselect the game window, a lot. The puzzles are extremely easy. The mechanics are horrid. The ragdoll physics and difficulty with grabbing objects in this game make make for an unpleasent experience.

PROS:
Few controls and plays well with gamepad.

Conclusion
Will I still finish it to the end? Perhaps.

I am on the fence on this one but I have to lean more towards not recommending. 

On one hand it has a simplistic charm and quirkyness that makes you want to see what's around the corner but on the other hand there are a mountain of issues plaguing the game.

The camera alone is enough to make you turn the game off and walk away immediately. Want to climb a ledge? The camera zooms into a face-first POV that then confuses your next set of actions resulting in the cause of many, many deaths. I used a controller for this game and the thumbsticks somehow control the camera and the humans arms at the same time and it is downright rage-inducing.

The controls leave something to be desired as well. The human acts as if he has had one too many beers and stumbles around and doesn't exactly do what you are telling him to do but does that action very closely which leaves room for many errors. This become an uphill battle when you are required to make simple "platform-esque" jumps and the human makes a half-hearted attempt and thus puts you back at the beginning of the puzzle. I shouldn't have to redo a portion of the game because the built-in controls are not doing what I want them to do.

I *HIGHLY* do not recommend playing this (if you decide to) in single player and go for local co-op as the tasks get exponentially easier with a second pair of awkward hands.

TL;DR
In the end, this games falls into the developers unique genre of "funky controls makes for hilarious gameplay!" but because of those controls & camera alone, it delivers something very far from "fun".

Great physics-based game that allows for a lot of goofy fun and really gives you freedom to do linear puzzles in several ways, some of which would allow you to skip it.

I was only able to play this though single-player, though have seen videos of the co-op play, and would agree with many other reviews that this is the way to go. The game's controls are far enough in the frustration side that for single player would lead to controller throwing would make for good laughs with a partner. While the game can be readily compared to Octodad in terms of concept, the game does have a number of puzzles that require preciseness and timing that Octodad did not require. Add that the camera is an essential part of the controls, and it can make for frustration.

Given all that, the game does a great job of presenting physics-based puzzles with a lot of good visual hints to guide you to the solution. There are not too many repeated puzzle elements, though when there is repetition, it is part of a learning scaffold to help you on the complex puzzles.  Not all the puzzles are straight forward, and some require experimentation -- and that's where the control frustration can set in - but most puzzles are reasonably self-contained in their own areas, so you can quickly come to the right solution. Checkpoints are frequent enough to not be a game-stopper.

It is not a bad puzzler, and outside of the control scheme issues, it's definiely a few hours of some good thoughtful challenges. Just be prepared to take a few breaks to avoid mental wear from the game.

To be honest I was expecting a little mediocre game to play for a short time with a friend. But the further we progressed through, the more delighted I was with original-feeling and clever puzzles. Trying to control our two heavily drunken human characters makes for a balanced mix of frustration and laughs. Then we found drivable vehicles and I was blown away with how well they worked in a game like this. Also I must mention that I haven't seen many cases of bendable (jail) bars in games, that was cool. Puzzles are made to be solved solo but have enough challenge to not be trivial with a friend.

We suffered a lot of framerate drops from time to time but didn't notice any bugs during our ~4 hour adventure. Overall a strong recommend if you can enjoy goofy physics puzzles, more so with a friend.

TL;DR Great puzzle game, Tomb Raider 1-like controls, very satisfying puzzle-solving, 50/50 level designs, a bit short in terms of length and levels available. Buy it when it goes on sale, though its SRP isn't half-bad if you're planning on playing it with a friend.

=============================

Finished it in ~6 hours on my own (without exploiting the wall-climbing mechanic), not because it's easy, but because I tend to just focus on a game when I have free time.



Human: Fall Flat is what you'd get if you mashed Gang Beasts's mushy character model (and some of its control mechanics) and Tomb Raider 1's controls scheme, assuming you were born around the time it first came out. It's mostly a puzzle game, but the challenge isn't just in solving the puzzles; it's pulling it off.

One of the main challenges (or draws, if you're not into this kinda thing) of the game is the control mechanics. You grab things with your left and right hands using the LMB/RMB respectively. Add to that the fact that you need to actually "look" in the direction you want your hands to lunge towards to and you'll either get annoyed the first few attempts of learning how to work it. While the camera *does* zoom in on your player character when you hold any of the mouse buttons, it doesn't lower your character's opacity, so it's a bit of trying to flail around your flappy ragdoll arms as well (and sometimes they can get stuck on your own body too.)

It gets more interesting when some of the puzzles require you to think beyond the usual "grab this and drop it here", since some of them actually have you operating vehicles (which are surprisingly fun to operate even on your lonesome) and catapults (which you actually wind down and trigger manually), as well as breaking walls or windows with objects lying around.

There is no "one" way of solving a puzzle or finishing this game. I believe I skipped out on some of the puzzles, not because I used the parkour exploit (yes, you can climb walls if you take the time to learn the mechanics enough), but because some of the puzzles i solved ended up with an object that helped me climb over a wall without having to "cheat" the climb. It's great, though some end-level bits were clearly designed to force you to go through certain doors (especially the first few levels).

The main "fun" aspect of the game is in solving the puzzles, as well as actually succeeding in pulling off whatever it is you need to do. Nine times out of ten, you're wrestling with the camera and your floppy ragdoll body, and depending on your temperament and willingness to succeed, this may or may not be obnoxious and detrimental to succeeding. Actually being able to grab onto that ledge while jumping off a falling pillar and expecting yourself to fail is immensely satisfying, as the "physics" puzzles tend to increase in terms of variety as the levels progress. Again, you can skip some of them, but where's the fun in that?

In its current state, it's hard to recommend it at its standard price point. Unless you're planning on playing with a friend locally (no online as of writing), it might be advisable to get it during a sale (which I did haha). It's technically a "finished" game, but it somehow felt a bit lacking. Not sure how to put it, but I feel like it's the lack of levels that's holding this game back, as the controls and feature list is already quite sound. 

It would be great to see more games like this where the player is given freedom of movement to this degree, without making it too easy for them to navigate the whole map. It was a refreshing experience, though I might just be a masochist for games that sacrifice standardized mechanics for new ideas.

[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review 

PLEASE NOTE (2017): Due to recent false accusations of plagarism, I (the reviewer) would like to stress that all these reviews and upcoming reviews are original and are not blatantly copied. Other reviews are used to help stress my point across but are changed in such a way to make the review in my own wording [/h1]

Human: Fall Flat is a game developed by No Brakes Games and pbulished by Curve Digital

The game takes physics puzzles to a new place and it is incredibly fun and enjoyable to play but the hardest part of this game is the controls, they are kinda finicky and awkward to play yet not completely annoying such as in Surgeon Simulator

Human: Fall Flat is a fun game to play by yourself or with friends in local multiplayer. Some things could be fixed in later patches and updates but overall it is a fun game to play in short bursts or with friends!

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

This is a great game for you if you like weird-ass games. As of writing this review, I've only played it single player, but I really think multiplayer would have been a lot of fun too. Unfortunately, It's only local multiplayer. 

The hardest part of this game is the controls. That's not to say that the controls are frustratingly hard or impossible to use in a semi functional way (like Surgeon Simulator), and it doesn't mean that how well you can "act normal" using the controls is an important part of the game (like in Octo-dad). Instead it's a fairly easy and entertaining puzzle game that is made a little more challenging because all of your character's limbs fell asleep one day and just never woke up. 

I love the game's style and it's humor is pretty great too. 

Overall, if you liked Octo-dad, thought Mount Your Friends was tolerable, and like puzzle games, this game is for you!

This game is incredibly funny and epic, I haven't seen anything as funny as it is for a very long time. 
It made me and my friend laugh until tears came to our eyes, and I am telling the truth, this is not an exaggeration.
In addition to its funny parts, there are tons of interesting puzzles which are quite chagllenging, It is so fulfilling after you solve a confusing puzzle that took you a long time.
It is your game if you want to laugh, have so much fun with your friend or whoever you want to share the game with.
10/10, though I haven't finished the game yet, I want MORE!!! 
Just buy it, for the love of god.

Candid Camera. Beadle's About. Trigger Happy TV. What do all of these things have in common? Enterainment based upon someone else's misfortune or their reaction to an annoying situation. You then also have shows like Takeshi's Castle  which are entertaining because of peoples epic fails at doing the most simple of tasks. And just like those shows, HFF is only entertaining when played with someone else. Let me explain.

In itself, the game is more about wrestling with the controls than puzzle solving. That may seem odd but this is really the fact. The puzzles are not hard. They aren't going to test your creative logic or have you pondering for hours with the answers staring you in the face with a cheeky grin. It's about managing to achieve a very simple task with completely inadaquet controls. HFF isn't even the first to do this since the days of Grow Home and Grow Up we've had procedureal animations kicking around and frankly HFF's controls are less tight by comparison and that works against it when it attempts to ask you to do something simple like jumping a gap or walking along a narrow edge. The only thing it does well it grasping and lifting objects. As a result, playing the game by yourself is extremely tedious. But when working with someone else it is extremely funny to see how your buddy is completely failing to perform even the simpliest of tasks. I guess the lesson here is that it is only entertaining when it isn't happening to you.

Given that there are many other games out there with amusing cooperative play it would be only fair to say that HFF is not something I can recommend because unless you have someone else with you the game just isn't entertaining. Furthermore it is very, very short and has absolutely zero replay value. If you want a game like this for solo go play Grow Up or Grow Home. If you want a good party game then try Gangbeasts or A Gummy's Life.

I came back to rewrite this review because it turns out this game has great replayability potential. 

Basically, in this game you run around, and you can reach out and grab stuff with both arms. There's some objects you need to pick up and use as levers and such, and there's some machines and platforming and opening doors and such. 

It doesn't sound exciting. But you know when you're drunk, and you can barely walk, and every simple task feels like a challenge? It's kind of like that. 

Not only that, but once you start to get the hang of what this game is, you can start breaking the rules. You can go off the beaten path, use items from the previous puzzles in new and exciting ways in the next one, you can climb to the top of all the things you thought were just there for decoration. 

And the sooner the better. Replaying the game, there's so much I realize I missed the first time through, because I was so busy finding shortcuts. Not only that, but sometimes I just didn't know what I was supposed to do, so I think I must've gone the wrong way. For instance, once I drove a boat into a wall so I could jump over it, I'm just now discovering where I was actually supposed to drive that boat. Not only that, but once I got there I found a secret area, leading to a part of the level I'd never seen before. I don't know how much more there is to this game, but it's a blast to go back and find out.

Great concept, poor gameplay execution

The idea of the game is great: drop you in (literally) by yourself into a funky world, and you have to figure out what to do. The problem is actually doing it. Your character has a wobbly, eratic, uncordinated nature - meaning that even once you figure out what to do, actually making your character do it is just as hard (or harder). For instance: grab a cane, hook it onto a peg, and swing on it. Sounds simple. But getting your character to pick it up, swing it, hook it, and then move - MUCH harder. Early in the game, it's not a huge problem, but as the game goes on, it can severely ruin the experience. It's not a challenge about doing something precisely - it's a challenge about getting your character to do basic functions (which just isn't fun). 

If they made the character easier to control, this would be great - or at least easier give you more precise movement as the game progresses - the game would be amazing. But given this fundamental issue, it really ruins the experience.

She doesn't really play many other video games, but this one is easily her favorite.

In Human: Fall Flat, you control a character who is either extremely drunk or just learning to walk for the first time. 

Your character is almost always in motion. Moving the mouse to change your view will cause the character to point its entire body in that direction, causing you to fall off of whatever ledge you were standing on. If you are standing on an incline, you will slide down that incline unless you hold down a key to keep yourself moving in the opposite direction.

This wouldn't be such a terrible shortcoming if the game didn't require you to use fine motor skills to accomplish tasks at every turn. Feeding a wire into a hole. Hooking four small hooks (on chains) onto the four corners of a shipping container. Driving a forklift with one hand on the steering wheel and one hand on the throttle. Pull starting a generator.

This game is incredibly frustrating to play. The puzzles are only difficult because the main character is difficult to control.
Camera bobbing makes me motion sick!

Very creative and intuitive controls. You're an average person with no special skills; you can run, jump, grab, push, pull and that's about it but that's what makes the game so creative. Every single action is manual, which means you shouldnt expect Assassins' Creed style climbing (hold this button and push analog stick that way). Your right trigger and analog stick controls your right hand, and your left trigger and analog stick controls your left hand, and you have to really think about every single button you're pressing and the exact timing to perfect climbing up the simplest of things. It's easy to understand but diffiult to master. Whenever you "fall flat" (and it will be often), you'll be frustrated, but at yourself and not at the game, as the controls are quick and responsive so you've got noone to blame but yourself. If you've played "Gang Beasts", it's basically that but better, with more things to do, and a "story-mode". 

Open ended level design means there is not one way to approach a situation, and leaves much to the imagination. You can pull levers, push buttons, drive vehicles, scale walls, leap gaps, row boats, pole vault rivers... the list goes on and on. If you can imagine it, then you can do it, it's all up to you as a player to pull it off with the controls that you are given. There are no "missions"; you're thrown into a world, and you just explore but you know which general direction you should be moving towards. The way the levels are designed is methodic and step-by-step without holding your hand too tightly. 

The possibilities are even greater in co-op, as you can interact with each other in ways that many games have explored but not perfected. You can climb, push, pull, throw, ride, tackle, save, and kill other players and it's mad fun. Something as simple as rowing a boat can be so exciting, chaotic and hilarious. 

I bought this game (and completed it) when it was still in Early Access. I played through the whole story with my girlfriend so I definitely recommend you play with another person too as that's where it really shines. We absolutely loved the game and she was surprised to hear that, at that point, the developers had not yet finished the game. I haven't played since, and I'm sure it could only have gotten better, and that is a large, large statement, as this game was already very, very good. Will come back when the free update is released, and if something compels me to change my opinion then I will be back to edit my review, but for now, I'm quite set on my decision.

86/100

A great physics puzzle game. I definetely reccomend it, but here's a list of Pros and Cons for those of you who are interested.

[h1] Pros: [/h1]

- Very well designed levels, it is clear that a lot of effort was put into making sure each one has multiple solutions, and all of them look beautiful.

- Fun, floppy character can be painted and customized, but still has a lot of personality as a blank slate.

- Very replayable, due to the ammount of freedom.

- Beautiful sound track. Even if you don't get this game, I'd suggest you buy it if you have money to spare.

- Very few physics glitches.

- fun even without multiplayer.

[h1] Cons: [/h1]

- After the first few levels, a more "suggested" path becomes clear, and sometimes the levels feel more like trying to put things together with your floppy arms than a puzzle, for an answer is immediately clear.

- Vehicles are more frustrating than fun.

- It seems like less effort was put into the last level, the ends of lava rivers can be clearly seen if you fall off the map, and falling into lava doesn't make you instantly respawn, you just fall through it. No real affect on gameplay though.

- The soundtrack doesn't seem to loop, once it's done, it stays done for a while or until you get to the next level.

All in all, a great game with only a few issues. Somewhat short, but if you'd spend $10 to go see an hour-and-a-half movie, $15 dollars is a great price for a week or two of a great singleplayer game.

This is some of the greatest couch co-op fun I've had in ages. I could play an entire (read: AAA length) game that was built with couch co-op in mind with these play mechanics. The game starts out strong with some really fun and interesting levels where the player(s) must get used to controlling their jello-like avatars through a series of virtual obstacle courses so to speak by grabbing onto surfaces and objects to manipulate their way towards the goal. However, the game is relatively short and could definitely have used more content, especially given the awesome premise and solid execution of what is here. I recommend this game based solely on the amount of sheer enjoyment I got out of it, though I do wish there were more of it to enjoy.

What a wonderful game. If you like whacky physics and great puzzles, this is for you.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]

+ the low poly look is great and really fits the game
+ the physics are outstanding, they work so well, even ropes and such never clip through
+ the puzzles are amazing and have more than one solution
+ you can custom paint your character
+ everything works with physics, pulling levers, swinging on ropes, breaking objects
+ driveable vehicles
+ a lot of new elements are introduced throughout the whole game, so levels never get old
+ music is great
+ even though the physics are whacky, you still have a lot of control over your character
+ level transitions are very creative
+ have fun and go numb, with the ragdoll button :)
+ controller support
+ I encountered no bug whatsoever
+ local multiplayer coop!

[h1]Cons:[/h1]

- I just whish there was a level editor and workshop support, so the game could go on with brilliant communtiy levels and creations

- at 5,5 hours the game is not too long, but I just enjoyed it so much, I really dont mind

At times I thought this is what tomb raider would be if Lara packed on the pounds. Timing jumps perfectly, swinging like tarzan, hurling yourself through the air like a damp washcloth waiting for an impact to stick to any available surface, operating vehicles and machines with the dexterity of a moose. Well maybe not the latter two but at times this game is unforgiving. Spent 5 minutes scaling a vertical wall, let go with the wrong hand, start again. Spent ages rowing a boat (painful until you get the motion right) but slipped overboard, start again.

My only problems are the length of the game (depending on play style and how quickly you get the controls), it lasts maybe 5-6 hours max (my play time is 2 run throughs and some split screen). Additionally, the last level feels a little unfinished, repetitive power based puzzles, when in previous levels you were solving varied challenges (physical skill, logic, creative thinking).

A fun customise feature lets you put your face on your character via webcam but you can also paint them to look however you like.

[i]Human: Fall Flat is simultaneously a joy and a chore to play. I wholeheartedly recommend the game for it's charm and unique approach to physics puzzles and level design.[/i]

Human strikes a great balance between giving you reasonable control of your motions without forcing you to micromanage them. Most of the time Human does what you expect, and the times it doesn't have more to do with learning what works (e.g. how to weild poles).

The level design harkens back to a time when games were far more varied. Yes the way you interact with each level is mostly the same, but very few set pieces are reused between levels keeping what would otherwise be a very tedious game more or less consistently interesting.

The achievements in the game also do wonders for the engagement with the game. Some are super easy, some are very vague, but they keep the game from becoming a simple "flop across the map" experience.

If you approach Human from the perspective that each level is a small sandbox and not a finely tuned experience I feel you'll get a lot more value out of the game. Be prepared to dick around, launch yourself from catapults, find alternate routes through a level, and get super frustrated by poles.

In a good puzzle game, finding the solution is the hard part, execution is easy. This game gets those reversed. You will find yourself fighting controls a good while after you've already figured out what to do.

The 'puzzle' that caused me to put the controller down involved driving up a long, windy road only to find out there was already an identical vehicle there and the puzzle that awaited me was monotonously puting coal on a conveyer belt so that I could drive back down that road and monotonously load the coal into a furnace.
A fun game that's challenging enough to be interesting, with enough simplicity to just dive right in and play it. Definitely worth the price.

Ultimate drunken baby simulator.

In human fall flat, you navigate environments with the goal of getting to the end. The catch? Your avatar is controlled by you. And not well (but in a fun charming way).  Each stick controls a hand. Triggers control the grips. Clumsily pick up items you need, manipulate objects, climb up walls, use controls, and more using your "drunken baby" avatar.  It sounds like an awful experience, but in reality it is fun and charming. It plays very similar (as I can tell) to gang beats.  It isn't surgeon simulator level of ridiculous. It is clumsly, but manageable.

Also:
- Future steam workshop for outfits and levels!
